intro: Palaquium obovatum var. occidentale, commonly known as the West Indian persimmon, is a small evergreen tree native to the Caribbean and parts of South America. It typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters and has glossy, elliptical leaves that are dark green on the upper surface and lighter on the underside. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that develop into edible berries, which are often consumed raw or used in local cuisine. Its fruit has a sweet, sometimes astringent flavor and is valued for its nutritional content. The tree is adapted to tropical climates and thrives in well-drained soil with ample sunlight.
